Comment: A bill that is not enacted in a 2 year Congress dies when that Congress adjourns. It can be reintroduced with a new bill number though.  The issue is that the composition of the house changes 100% every 2 years, creating a “new” Congress, whereas the Senate changes 1/3 every 2 years, so you lose the votes that said yes/no when that Congress adjourns, necessitating a new vote in both houses.  For our purposes, that happens after the midterms (2023 change of Congress)
Author: apatheticviews

Comment: In a different note, let’s say bill X1 passes the Senate. The house gets bill X1, makes some minor changes, and then passes it as bill X1.1. Bill X1.1 must pass the senate with no further modifications before the president can sign it. If the Senate modifies it again before passing (now bill X1.2), then the House must pass it w/o modifications before the president signs (and so on). The exact same version of the bill must pass the House and Senate during the same session of Congress to become law.

Comment: Correct, any bills voted before January in House OR Senate dies on Jan 3, 2023 (end of 117th Congress).  It doesn’t matter whether they think they will win or lose the other House, the bill dies, and must be revoted on.  As an example, let’s say on Jan 2, the house passes “the awesome bill” unanimously and the senate is expected to pass it as well. Unfortunately the Senate gets food poisoning at the Congress cafeteria and is sick until Jan 4. There is NO change of seats in either the House or the senate (everyone won re-election). “The awesome bill” would still have to be re-voted on in the house AND the senate once congress is back in session

Comment: It's worth noting that this is true up until the bill is signed.   If both houses pass it and the president doesn't sign before the session ends, it's a "pocket veto"  Notably used to stop a bill without going on the record about it.    One party can do something similar to kill a bill where they just never vote on it in the chamber they control without going on record opposing it.
